page.title: 19Breamore-A Brief Botany
page.content: Breamore Parish extends from the banks of the Avon to the chalk downland. Although much of the land is intensively farmed, many habitats for wild flowers remain. On the river banks are yellow iris, flowering rush and trifid bur marigold.Not far away,marsh marigolds and purple loosestrife colour the former water meadows,now permanent pasture. {"The Marsh",}a 60-acre common surrounded by thatched cottages,is yellow with buttercups in June,while meadowsweet,hemlock and great willowherb line the streams. At the edges of fields of corn,poppies field pansies and corn marigolds still flourish, if in much reduced numbers. The churchyard wall harbours greater celandine and ivy-leaved toadflax. In the shade of{Breamore Wood,}areas are
